newsitem.title: USA: U.S. foreign crude activity light, Urals deal seen.
newsitem.headline: U.S. foreign crude activity light, Urals deal seen.

text.p: U.S. foreign crudes remained only moderately busy Friday, well below normal levels, though some talk was generated for mid-to-late September arrivals.
A major U.S. trade house was heard selling a cargo of Russian Urals to its own refining arm, for late September delivery to the U.S. Gulf. Prices were not known.
A Latin America trader was also heard shopping an August 28-30 Urals cargo for late September delivery into Cuba.
A crude broker said the timing of the Urals cargo into the U.S. Gulf was highly unusual.
"It's not out of the question to have the Urals shipped over, just the timing," said the broker.
Other talk in the foreign market had Oseberg offered for September 25-30 around 5 cents over October West Texas Intermediate/Cushing.
Brent cargoes were offered at 10-15 cents under October WTI for the same late September delivery.
"The talk is still very expensive for end September. There aren't as many deals because of the high prices, at least compared to last month," said a trader.
North Sea cargoes were also being talked up, with a Hydra cargo heard coming over in late September.
In the U.S. aftermarket, traders said a number of partial paper cargoes were dealt at firmer levels.
A major U.S. trade house was the big buyer in the window, takingup 350 lots of October Brent at $20.50, and a smaller 100 lot slice at $20.55. Brent Sep/Oct was sold at 48 cents, traders said.
